raw_text: I suck at friendships. I'm an extremely solitary, introverted & asocial person with low functioning mental health issues - I tried so hard for years pretending to be otherwise because I was told countless times that it's not "normal" or "healthy". Eventually I became so exhausted of trying to maintain this bullshit facade that one day I just stopped giving a shit. I no longer cared to meet peoples arbitrary standards of normality as long as I was happy & harming no one. After that I just kinda stopped cultivating friendships. If I have to maintain or make them for whatever reason I keep them at a very superficial level. I don't expect things from them except pleasant company from time to time. I don't use them for emotional support. I don't tell them about my problems. I don't share much about me. I don't get too involved in their life. I've found it to be easiest if I keep the relationships light & often fleeting. As if we're just friendly acquaintances. I figured if I'm going to be a bad friend then at the very least I shouldn't take from people what I can't give back in return.

raw_text: I think the media has a lot to do with the phenomena, honestly. Every time a thread like this pops up "not like other girls" types chime in that they *can't* make female friends because the women they see "wear makeup" or "do their hair" or something equally surface level. Maybe in movies that's supposed to say a lot about someone, but in real life the fact that a girl I know does or doesn't wear makeup tells me practically *nothing* about whether or not I'd get along with them. *Of course* if you buy into every teen movie you've ever seen you think you're "not like other girls", those girls are portrayed horribly and exceptionally one dimensionally. Practically no one in real life, not even the Kardashians or Paris Hilton types, are that devoid of depth. It's funny because usually they're coming at it from the angle of "I'm not superficial and they are", but *they're* the ones deciding who they will or won't be friends with based on their style. That's *wayyyyyyyyy* more superficial than slipping on some lipstick or curling your hair.And of course there's no real male equivalent for their guy friends. "Oh he shaves his stubble daily, he's way too high maintenance we could never be friends" Smart, capable, cool women style themselves in every single way imaginable. Michelle Obama is gorgeous, always wearing something stylish, does her makeup, etc. *And* has two ivy league degrees, among a laundry list of other accomplishments. Imagine avoiding her as a friend because she's "too feminine" or "basic" at first glance. I also hate the idea that comes along with all this, that you can only be successful friends with people who are *exactly like you.* That's so goddamn boring and not true. I'm 24 and have two friends in their 70s. I'm not very athletic and I have friends that might as well be olympic athletes. I have friends that are waaaaay less nerdy than me. We don't have everything in common but we all have chemistry, and I learn a lot from my friends that aren't the exact same "type" of girl or person as me. People need to give each other a shot and challenge the stereotypes they hold.

raw_text: Like, yeah. I pretty much spent my entire early adulthood pretending I didn’t have needs so men would like me. It would work, and we’d start dating. Then I’d get progressively more resentful and fearful and eventually blow up because I was too overwhelmed to effectively express what was wrong, apologize and beg forgiveness for being “crazy,” further suppress my needs, and repeat the cycle. Cool girl behavior didn’t just come up in relationships, either — I’d sit and laugh along with male “friends” saying objectifying and misogynistic shit about other women that bothered me deep down because I wanted to be “one of the guys” and felt special that they were comfortable talking about that stuff around me. More than a few of them got creepy and crossed boundaries with me, and a lot of times, it took me way too long to put my foot down and tell them to fuck off. I found that this strategy was very effective in attracting men into my life who did not believe women should need consistency or respect or have needs different from their own. It wasn’t great for attracting men who actually treated me well or contributed to my happiness. I got burned particularly badly in my last relationship (which started with cool girl behavior and generally entailed a lot of doormat shit from me) and decided in the midst of that pain that I’d rather die alone than take another trip around that carousel. So I started asking men for what I needed and expected from the get-go and realized that if dudes who couldn’t meet my needs left or rejected me, that was a good thing. I ended up falling out with a couple of male friends because of this, but it was for the best. Eventually, I found a great, super-attuned guy who is very kind to me and takes my feelings into account when making decisions. :)

raw_text: I was definitely a "not like other girls" type in middle school & high school, but never to be the cool girl. I wasn't generally fond of boys either so their attention wasn't my goal. I was just pissed off about everything, intellectually superior, and dressed like I wanted to be left alone, so I didn't exactly draw the eye. Part of the problem was a heavy insecurity about my looks, so I lorded my "smarts" over other girls to feel better than them. Once I hit about 17 and up, I found ways to deal with my emotional issues, had finished some acne medication, and chose more flattering clothes. I started to get a lot of attention, which helped my insecurities (not very progressive, but that's the truth), and once I started feeling a little better about myself I realized what a hateful shit I was and how important kindness is. I started practicing humility and threw in a little self-deprecating goofiness to make myself approachable. I also accepted the fact that my sexuality was a mess, and I quite liked other girls, actually, but still had to train myself against snap judgments on them. And I accepted that I have a pretty average intelligence. I just liked to read, so my grammar was a step above my peers'.

title: I (18/f) have an embarrassing ‘condition’. Should I tell the guy (18/m) I like or would it creep him out? (nsfw)
selftext:
This is an awkward problem...

So I recently met this guy through mutual friends and felt instantly attracted to him. Lately we started hanging out alone more and he’s just amazing. Cute, smart and pretty shy but I like it. Not sure if he feels the same way about me but he always wants to hang out so I hope that’s a good sign. I only have one problem....

My ‘condition’ (couldn’t think of a more fitting word) is that I sneeze when I’m aroused. Yes, really. Whenever I have a sexual thought or get turned on I get these sneezing fits. I use nasal sprays to keep things under control. 

Anyway, whenever I hang out with this guy I start sneezing as soon as I see him. At the beginning I told him that it’s just a cold (it wasn’t) and that I’m very sensitive during cold seasons (I’m not). I kept lying about it and he probably thought I’m just a sickly person. For a while he even encouraged me to go to the doc but I told him that it’s not a serious problem. 

The problem is that he’s slowly putting the pieces together but he’s taking it the wrong way. He pointed out that I only sneeze when I’m around him, not others. For example one time he saw me talk to a friend and I was fine, when I came up to him and we hugged I sneezed. He joked that I’m obviously allergic to him and that I should just be honest if I can’t stand him. 


So should I tell him the truth or would it be too creepy? At this point we’re pretty comfortable around each other but I don’t wanna make things weird. Would it freak him out? 

**TL;DR I sneeze when I’m physically aroused. Should I tell this guy I really like or would it be creepy?**

title: [Update!] My [27F] husband [29M] is verbally abusive and possibly gay/bi?
selftext:
[Original Post](https://www.reddit.com/r/relationship_advice/comments/ej8ti0/my_27f_husband_29m_is_verbally_abusive_and/)

I left. I called a cop to come stand outside while I got my things. He teared up a bit, and then asked why we couldn't talk about it. We have talked about it so many times. He told me it was embarrassing that I called the cops. When I was finished packing, I asked him for my spare car key and he said "I don't have my keys with me. You didn't warn me you were calling the cops. If I'm allowed inside I can go get them." \*Eye Roll.\*  He truly did not understand why I called the cops. I never thought he would lay a hand on me, but I didn't want to risk anything. I was worried he'd try to keep me there to talk, or let the air out of my tires again.

He then told me he had been thinking about suicide. Maybe he said it to make me feel bad, but I told him to seek therapy because I want him to be happy and figure out his issues. He told me he listed out all of our issues and that it was less than 10 things. I'm not sure how that was supposed to make me feel better.

I am back at my mom's and he is currently packing his things and going to Florida to visit his family. I have been in contact with his brother since I found out about the coke and he has been very supportive of my decision, along with my sister and a close friend of mine.

Thank you, redditors, for helping me taking the leap. I am extremely sad, but not regretful of my decision. I would've loved to work things out, but realistically it is just not possible. I cannot change the hurt he caused me. I cannot convince him to be honest with me or himself. I am ultimately enabling him to treat me like shit by staying in this marriage, and I will not accept that for him or myself. I would also be doing him a disservice by not allowing him to explore his sexuality and discover who he really is.

title: My date just rejected me [22/M] after I mentioned crying during movies.
selftext:
Last night I went on a date with a girl whom I matched with on Tinder and we had a pretty good time while we went out for coffee. We talked about some pretty basic stuff and when we got to the subject of movies, she started talking about movies that have made her cry. She mentioned the usual stuff like Titanic and The Notebook, and then I chimed in by saying that I cried during A Star is Born, the ending song scene specifically. My date shot me a weird look and said "Wait...you cried during it?" I asked her if something was wrong and she said "I mean, it's cute when girls cry during movies, but it's weird when guys do it." After that, there was this really awkward silence and we parted ways not long after that.

Then she texted me this morning and she simply said to me "I don't think things are going to work out." She didn't mention a specific reason, but I feel like it's very likely that the subject of crying during movies is what she was alluding to. We were getting along really well until then and now I'm wondering what I did wrong and I'm trying to rack my brain over this whole thing.

title: My [21F] boyfriend's [23M] relationship with his teddybear is making me uncomfortable
selftext:
Okay now please no joke this is actually serious. Also, this is a throwaway account and I was an idiot when writing my name and typed throwaway instead of throwra.

I have been with my boyfriend for 3 months now, so it's pretty new. So far everything is going well except this tiny little detail. He has this teddy bear, let's name him Teddy. Teddy has always been a part of my boyfriend's life : he got him for his birth and when at around the age of 5 or 6 (or whatever age is the appropriate age to remove a teddy bear from a child) his parents tried taking Teddy away from him, he screamt and cried so loud without stopping they ended up giving up. So he kept Teddy with him his whole life. 

He mentionned Teddy to me pretty early, about a week after us being together. He showed me pictures of him and I found it cute at first. He had plenty of pictures of him in different situations (him with a mug, him laying in bed, him studying...). I truly found it adorable since I thought it was just a joke really and didn't think that Teddy was such a big part of his life. The more we got to know eachother the more he started mentionning him. He'd often make jokes about him. When he had to come back to his flat, he'd say "I have to come back Teddy is waiting for me" and then later he'd text me "ok I put Teddy to bed so now I might go to sleep as well i don't want to wake him up". Again, a little weird but cute still. But he really started talking about him constantly, always linking what we were doing to him ("Oh I wish Teddy was with us to see that", "Teddy doesn't really like people so I won't take him with me for this party" etc...) . He'd send me selfies with him at least twice a week.

He also sometimes said weird stuff like whenever we watched a sex scene in a movie he'd say "that's what me and Teddy do when we're alone" or when i asked when he lost his virginity he answered "oh I lost it with Teddy a few years ago". They were jokes that made me uncomfortable. He always seemt to consider him as a baby/his son/his brother, so him being sexualised was extremely weird for me. I told him then that it was weird and he just laughed but I don't think he took me seriously.

About a month ago, I told him I was okay with him bringing Teddy when he was staying around my flat. I could see it was making him sad to leave him, and also was very curious to finally see him in person (I can't go to my boyfriend's flat, there are rules that are strict, he can't invite anyone). So that day I drove to his flat and he went with all his stuff and Teddy. When he got in the car he pulled him out from his bag and had him give me a kiss on the cheek. When we drove, he opened the window and put Teddy out of the car (a bit like a dog would). He said it was rare for Teddy to travel like that and he could feel that he was happy. Teddy smells a lot, my boyfriend hasn't washed him in 12 YEARS. For the rest of the car drive, he hugged him and gave him kisses.

He has weird "twitch" where he just compulsively pats the back of Teddy (it makes a weird sound because Teddy used to be able to play music when you pressed his belly). He always rubs Teddy's clothes inbetween his fingers (you can guess that Teddy is in a pretty bad state, he used to be red and now he's just grey). When we're together in bed, he always puts Teddy's mouth on my mouth and I always avoid it as I find it disgusting (and I told him that I hate it but he doesn't listen). He always tries to have Teddy touch my boobs or my arse. He often mentions us having a threesome with Teddy, him (Teddy) being great at licking, and them always doing kinky stuff together.

Now I'm not an idiot. I know communication is important. I tried talking to him so many times. Sometimes in a joking way too so he doesn't feel attacked (like once, I asked who would he choose if he had to choose between me and Teddy, he said Teddy), but also so many times in a serious way (I told him I didn't like when he was rubbing Teddy on my face and body, I told him I found his relationship with him way too intense and weird) but every time he didn't take it seriously, made jokes, and never truly told me what he thought. I should mention that he is like that for any serious conversation, all he does is make awkward jokes and he never tells me how he feels (he said I love you first because he was drunk).

This is becoming hard to handle. I have been away from him for two weeks and was kind of relieved I wouldn't see Teddy anymore, but all he did was send pictures, and whenever I asked him "what are you doing" or "what did you do today" is answer was "playing with Teddy". Today he told me I was perfect, which was a first and I sure didn't expect that (he doesn't give a lot of compliment). When he said that I said "really ?" and his reply was "actually no, Teddy is perfect, you come way after him". I just gave up and didn't reply.

I have 3 questions. 1) Am I overreacting, am I the one not being tolerant enough, am I some boring girlfriend who can't welcome some childishness in her couple ? 2) What should I do, should I let him live his life with Teddy, should I ask him to make a real choice, should I ask him to just stop the sexual jokes... Like, who am I to ask such things I don't know ? Is it my place to tell him to stop being so weird with his teddy bear ? And 3) How do I get him to finally talk to me and take me seriously ?

raw_text: Okay now please no joke this is actually serious. Also, this is a throwaway account and I was an idiot when writing my name and typed throwaway instead of throwra. I have been with my boyfriend for 3 months now, so it's pretty new. So far everything is going well except this tiny little detail. He has this teddy bear, let's name him Teddy. Teddy has always been a part of my boyfriend's life : he got him for his birth and when at around the age of 5 or 6 (or whatever age is the appropriate age to remove a teddy bear from a child) his parents tried taking Teddy away from him, he screamt and cried so loud without stopping they ended up giving up. So he kept Teddy with him his whole life. He mentionned Teddy to me pretty early, about a week after us being together. He showed me pictures of him and I found it cute at first. He had plenty of pictures of him in different situations (him with a mug, him laying in bed, him studying...). I truly found it adorable since I thought it was just a joke really and didn't think that Teddy was such a big part of his life. The more we got to know eachother the more he started mentionning him. He'd often make jokes about him. When he had to come back to his flat, he'd say "I have to come back Teddy is waiting for me" and then later he'd text me "ok I put Teddy to bed so now I might go to sleep as well i don't want to wake him up". Again, a little weird but cute still. But he really started talking about him constantly, always linking what we were doing to him ("Oh I wish Teddy was with us to see that", "Teddy doesn't really like people so I won't take him with me for this party" etc...) . He'd send me selfies with him at least twice a week. He also sometimes said weird stuff like whenever we watched a sex scene in a movie he'd say "that's what me and Teddy do when we're alone" or when i asked when he lost his virginity he answered "oh I lost it with Teddy a few years ago". They were jokes that made me uncomfortable. He always seemt to consider him as a baby/his son/his brother, so him being sexualised was extremely weird for me. I told him then that it was weird and he just laughed but I don't think he took me seriously. About a month ago, I told him I was okay with him bringing Teddy when he was staying around my flat. I could see it was making him sad to leave him, and also was very curious to finally see him in person (I can't go to my boyfriend's flat, there are rules that are strict, he can't invite anyone). So that day I drove to his flat and he went with all his stuff and Teddy. When he got in the car he pulled him out from his bag and had him give me a kiss on the cheek. When we drove, he opened the window and put Teddy out of the car (a bit like a dog would). He said it was rare for Teddy to travel like that and he could feel that he was happy. Teddy smells a lot, my boyfriend hasn't washed him in 12 YEARS. For the rest of the car drive, he hugged him and gave him kisses. He has weird "twitch" where he just compulsively pats the back of Teddy (it makes a weird sound because Teddy used to be able to play music when you pressed his belly). He always rubs Teddy's clothes inbetween his fingers (you can guess that Teddy is in a pretty bad state, he used to be red and now he's just grey). When we're together in bed, he always puts Teddy's mouth on my mouth and I always avoid it as I find it disgusting (and I told him that I hate it but he doesn't listen). He always tries to have Teddy touch my boobs or my arse. When we make love, I often end up finding him inbetween us and every time I throw him away my bf says "oh no he likes to watch" in a joking way. He often mentions us having a threesome with Teddy, him (Teddy) being great at licking, and them always doing kinky stuff together. Now I'm not an idiot. I know communication is important. I tried talking to him so many times. Sometimes in a joking way too so he doesn't feel attacked (like once, I asked who would he choose if he had to choose between me and Teddy, he said Teddy), but also so many times in a serious way (I told him I didn't like when he was rubbing Teddy on my face and body, I told him I found his relationship with him way too intense and weird) but every time he didn't take it seriously, made jokes, and never truly told me what he thought. I should mention that he is like that for any serious conversation, all he does is make awkward jokes and he never tells me how he feels (he said I love you first because he was drunk). This is becoming hard to handle. I have been away from him for two weeks and was kind of relieved I wouldn't see Teddy anymore, but all he did was send pictures, and whenever I asked him "what are you doing" or "what did you do today" is answer was "playing with Teddy". Today he told me I was perfect, which was a first and I sure didn't expect that (he doesn't give a lot of compliment). When he said that I said "really ?" and his reply was "actually no, Teddy is perfect, you come way after him". I just gave up and didn't reply. I have 3 questions. 1) Am I overreacting, am I the one not being tolerant enough, am I some boring girlfriend who can't welcome some childishness in her couple ? 2) What should I do, should I let him live his life with Teddy, should I ask him to make a real choice, should I ask him to just stop the sexual jokes... Like, who am I to ask such things I don't know ? Is it my place to tell him to stop being so weird with his teddy bear ? And 3) How do I get him to finally talk to me and take me seriously ? ​ TLDR : my bf has a weird relationship with his teddy bear, he considers him as a baby/a son but still makes very sexual jokes about him, often involving me by having him touch my body and it's making uncomfortable, what can I do.

title: My (23F) boyfriend and I (23F) live on his parents farm. We're on the brink of being kicked out because he didn't feed the horses which his only job.
selftext:
I'm a university student studying environmental science. My university campus for my course is just down the road from their farm. Before I lived here, I had to drive an hour and a half to get to this campus. It's one of the best universities for the course because of how diverse the environment is close to the campus. Forrest, farm land, lakes etc. It's made my life a lot easier. 

My boyfriend really isn't doing much since he dropped out of university last year. We're living on the farm rent free. My boyfriend really just sits around the house doing nothing. He only has the job of feeding the horses and putting them back in the barn. 

Three weeks ago, his father came banging on the door of our house/unit. He told my boyfriend to put his fucking shoes on and follow him. He took us to the paddock where the horses where. He wanted to know why they were left out all night and hadn't been fed. He pointed to Kyle (15M) taking the horses into the barn and told him that his younger brother is doing his job now. The last thing his father said is that it's his only fucking job to make sure they're warm and fed. He said we're gone the next time this happens. 

My boyfriend has been so lax in everything to do with it. I have to nag him to go outside and check on the horses and he half asses it. He didn't lock the barn two nights ago or made sure they had water. Kyle told me about it and said he wouldn't tell his dad, but make sure it didn't happen in the future.

raw_text: I'm a university student studying environmental science. My university campus for my course is just down the road from their farm. Before I lived here, I had to drive an hour and a half to get to this campus. It's one of the best universities for the course because of how diverse the environment is close to the campus. Forrest, farm land, lakes etc. It's made my life a lot easier. My boyfriend really isn't doing much since he dropped out of university last year. We're living on the farm rent free. My boyfriend really just sits around the house doing nothing. He only has the job of feeding the horses and putting them back in the barn. Three weeks ago, his father came banging on the door of our house/unit. He told my boyfriend to put his fucking shoes on and follow him. He took us to the paddock where the horses where. He wanted to know why they were left out all night and hadn't been fed. He pointed to Kyle (15M) taking the horses into the barn and told him that his younger brother is doing his job now. The last thing his father said is that it's his only fucking job to make sure they're warm and fed. He said we're gone the next time this happens. My boyfriend has been so lax in everything to do with it. I have to nag him to go outside and check on the horses and he half asses it. He didn't lock the barn two nights ago or made sure they had water. Kyle told me about it and said he wouldn't tell his dad, but make sure it didn't happen in the future.

title: I (32F) just found out my youngest daughter (11F) has been crying herself to sleep each night.
selftext:
I left her father last year after years of being in an abusive relationship. I never told the kids or ever let them see us fighting, as far as they knew we were happy, we just liked to pick on each other every now and again, at least that's how we made it seem in front of them. 

I have since moved on and am currently in a healthy and happy relationship with a man who goes out of his way to make sure my girls and I are happy. Earlier tonight my oldest messaged me on Facebook from their room to tell me that LT (my youngest) has been crying herself to sleep every night over this. I guess my oldest would calm her down and keep it secret because LT asked that but tonight was just too much. 

I went upstairs and LT was curled up pretending to be asleep but you could see the tears on her cheek. I told my oldest to leave the room so I could talk to LT. I asked her what was wrong and she said she missed her father, that she couldn't remember what he looked like. Side note: He doesn't see them that often, not because I keep them from him but because he lives an hour away and doesn't like to make the drive down here to see them. He can't have the kids at his house due to its condition. He was down this last weekend though due to the holidays and our oldest daughter's bday... I reminded her that she had just seen him over the weekend but she was still upset. She then asked why her father and I divorced. From day 1 I told her that while her dad and I still love each other, we agreed we are better friends than we are a couple. I did not go into details regarding the abuse or how he would neglect them to play on a computer etc. She didn't quite understand so I tried to put it in a way she would by using a friend of hers. They get along but they aren't best friends, same with her dad and I. She then asked about a song I used to sing to her 'You are my Sunshine' and asked if I would sing it to her. I pulled her into my lap and rocked her while I sang until she started to fall asleep then I put her in bed. 

My question for everyone is, how can I help with this? She already sees a councilor, but I think she's hiding a lot of feelings. I lied a little to her, her dad and I aren't exactly friends. I do try to keep in touch with him as we agreed on shared parenting. I tried to call him so she could speak with him but he wouldn't answer. I just told her he must be sleeping (he's not, he works night shift so right now is his daytime) I spoke with my guy about it and he doesn't know what to do either. Should I arrange for him to spend some quality time with the girls or would that make it worse on her and make her miss her father more? I don't know what to do.

TL;DR- Youngest is upset that her father and I divorced a year ago and cries herself to sleep each night. Already seeing a therapist but I'm thinking she may be hiding feelings. Need advice on how to help.

title: My(34M) wife(33F) who is about to leave this world in a few days just revealed to me she had an affair with my deceased brother(30M) last year while we were married.
selftext:
A lot has happened, and I'm not sure how to react and take it all in. In short, I had a brother who passed away in a freak accident while on vacation. It was a terrible time for our family, and it took me two months before I could move on from it. My brother was my family, growing we'd share secrets, play games, laugh, etc. There was brotherly love. 

A few months later, my wife diagnosed with a condition which cut her life short, I cried for that entire week since I had no one in this world apart from my wife. We have no kids, live a small live in city, that was it. 

My wife is very sick and we both know her time is coming up. I'm trying to make the best out of it, cooking for her, telling her stories, anything to take her mind off things. She can't help but cry to think of how I'm going to live for the rest of my life. 

&#x200B;

Last night while talking, my wife revealed to me that she had a short affair with my brother that lasted around one month. I couldn't believe it but the way she said it, I think shes telling the truth. 

&#x200B;

I don't know how to react. I hate her but still love her. I cant help but cry for minutes, then get enraged, then cry again. Its been a cycle for the past 6 hours. I'm not sure how I'll react seeing her again. Part of me doesn't want to see her again, part of me thinks its cruel to not see her in her final moments. What do I do? What would be the right thing? Who do I go to for support and counseling?

title: [UPDATE] I [25M] talked with my girlfriend [23F] about not wanting to have kids. She said that her having a child was a dealbreaker, I said it might have to be, and then things got a bit ugly. She's visiting family for the weekend and coming back on Sunday to "discuss this further."
selftext:
[Previous post here.](https://www.reddit.com/r/relationship_advice/comments/eilahp/my_girlfriend_23f_of_2_years_doesnt_want_kids/)

I'm going to try and keep this post a little shorter than the previous one, I promise!

I told her about my desire to have kids, and at first I don't think she thought I was seriously considering breaking up with her and was sympathetic and tried to make me feel better (lots of "I love you so much, we'll figure this out, etc"). She said that the dealbreaker was her having a kid, and I said I wanted to have a biological child of my own so it might have to be. She changed almost instantly and started swearing, saying "this isn't fucking happening", "What the fuck, do you know who I am? I don't give second chances.", and said she would take our 2 cats and all of her belongings (which  I said yes to and threw her off as she was expecting me to fight that), then berated me for wanting to bring a child into the world when there are already so many and how dare I force a woman to go through childbirth. She said I might not even be able to have kids because of my low testosterone (which is true, but irrelevant and a **very** low blow), tried to tell me how expensive kids are (which I already know) then pivoted and said she was open to adoption/surrogacy/fostering despite what she'd just said and her consistency the past 2 years in not wanting kids (and just a few minutes before she'd said that our parenting styles with the cats were so different that having a kid would probably tear us apart). 

All of this ended with her saying that if I truly loved her I would fix this, and that I wasn't breaking up with her and she'd be back Sunday to "discuss this further." before walking out and saying that she couldn't believe I'd brought this up and that she'd been looking forward to one of the long goodnight texts I used to send before we lived together.

So. I feel like I **probably** made the correct decision, given some of the things she said and how she reacted/twisted things. She also tried to make me out as a bad person by saying "How dare you say that I either have to have your baby or break up with you." Which... I guess if you want to twist things around to make me look bad that's the way to do it. I didn't **want** to break up with her, but given her positions and my wants I don't see another way around it. I tried to be as cordial and calm as I could be the whole time. I had to ask her to stop firmly when she went into the low testosterone issue, but aside from that I mostly stuck to apologizing and trying to deal with her changing her stance/position every few minutes.

Here's my questions this time:

1. I've been in an abusive relationship before, and the phrase "If you truly love me you'll fix this." sounds dangerously close to some of the things my ex used to say. Is that actually as abusive as I feel it is, or am I letting my past experiences color my perception of this interaction too much?
2. I've basically made up my mind, especially with how she treated me and some of the things she said today. Yes, I know I hurt her (and dear god did I feel horrible about that), but she basically spent the better part of an hour berating me for wanting to have a child and tried very hard to spin me as a bad person/make me feel bad. That alone is enough in my books to merit the end of our relationship. That being said, I could use some advice on how to handle the "continuation" of this conversation come Sunday. I know she's going to go home and research the cost of a kid, the cost of adoption/fostering/surrogacy, etc to try and throw in my face to argue me into agreeing with her.

Thanks again for all the advice from last time. I appreciated it, and I honestly do feel like I made the right choice. Just need a little more help figuring out how to handle the last little bit of this.

raw_text: [Previous post here.]( I'm going to try and keep this post a little shorter than the previous one, I promise! I told her about my desire to have kids, and at first I don't think she thought I was seriously considering breaking up with her and was sympathetic and tried to make me feel better (lots of "I love you so much, we'll figure this out, etc"). She said that the dealbreaker was her having a kid, and I said I wanted to have a biological child of my own so it might have to be. She changed almost instantly and started swearing, saying "this isn't fucking happening", "What the fuck, do you know who I am? I don't give second chances.", and said she would take our 2 cats and all of her belongings (which I said yes to and threw her off as she was expecting me to fight that), then berated me for wanting to bring a child into the world when there are already so many and how dare I force a woman to go through childbirth. She said I might not even be able to have kids because of my low testosterone (which is true, but irrelevant and a **very** low blow), tried to tell me how expensive kids are (which I already know) then pivoted and said she was open to adoption/surrogacy/fostering despite what she'd just said and her consistency the past 2 years in not wanting kids (and just a few minutes before she'd said that our parenting styles with the cats were so different that having a kid would probably tear us apart). All of this ended with her saying that if I truly loved her I would fix this, and that I wasn't breaking up with her and she'd be back Sunday to "discuss this further." before walking out and saying that she couldn't believe I'd brought this up and that she'd been looking forward to one of the long goodnight texts I used to send before we lived together. So. I feel like I **probably** made the correct decision, given some of the things she said and how she reacted/twisted things. She also tried to make me out as a bad person by saying "How dare you say that I either have to have your baby or break up with you." Which... I guess if you want to twist things around to make me look bad that's the way to do it. I didn't **want** to break up with her, but given her positions and my wants I don't see another way around it. I tried to be as cordial and calm as I could be the whole time. I had to ask her to stop firmly when she went into the low testosterone issue, but aside from that I mostly stuck to apologizing and trying to deal with her changing her stance/position every few minutes. Here's my questions this time: 1. I've been in an abusive relationship before, and the phrase "If you truly love me you'll fix this." sounds dangerously close to some of the things my ex used to say. Is that actually as abusive as I feel it is, or am I letting my past experiences color my perception of this interaction too much? 2. I've basically made up my mind, especially with how she treated me and some of the things she said today. Yes, I know I hurt her (and dear god did I feel horrible about that), but she basically spent the better part of an hour berating me for wanting to have a child and tried very hard to spin me as a bad person/make me feel bad. That alone is enough in my books to merit the end of our relationship. That being said, I could use some advice on how to handle the "continuation" of this conversation come Sunday. I know she's going to go home and research the cost of a kid, the cost of adoption/fostering/surrogacy, etc to try and throw in my face to argue me into agreeing with her. Thanks again for all the advice from last time. I appreciated it, and I honestly do feel like I made the right choice. Just need a little more help figuring out how to handle the last little bit of this.

title: My (33/M) wife (31/F) accused me of slapping her in front of a group of friends. It never happened.
selftext:
My wife and I have been married since we were very young (21/19). Our marriage has some minor issues, but more like "slowly dying" issues and not domestic violence issues. I've never posted here before and never thought something like this would happen to me. This incident occurred on New Year's Eve. 

We were drinking and having a good time playing some card games and waiting for midnight with a group of friends. One of the guys made an off-color joke about domestic violence, to which one of the girls got (rightfully) offended because she had been a victim of DV in the past. He didn't mean anything by it and apologized, and we seemed to be moving on.

Suddenly my wife blurts out: "Jim slapped me once". I looked at her expecting to hear some kind of joke, but she had a serious look on her face. Everyone was kind of puzzled, but then she told this story about how when we were first married that we got into a big fight and I supposedly lost my temper and slapped her in the face.

This never happened. Anyone who knows me knows that I am not a violent person. I've never hit anyone. I've never even been in a fight in school. I'm the youngest and smallest of four brothers and would routinely get my ass kicked by them, so reacting violently to situations was never my thing. I've never even raised my voice at my wife, which is something she's always hated about me because she feels like I don't show emotion.

My friends (male and female) immediately jumped to my defense and said they didn't believe her. Even her own best friend who's known me as long as we've been married didn't seem to believe her.

At this point my wife gets upset at the fact that no one believes her and starts to cry. She then starts trying to justify the situation and said that she was the one who was hitting me first and that I responded by slapping her back. The first part is true as she did attack me physically several times  in the early years, but I thought we worked through that and nothing like it has happened in a long time. However, again, I NEVER struck her back.

One of our friends started talking about false memories and how sometimes we remember things differently as a kind of way to change the conversation. Naturally the party took a weird turn after that and everyone left right after midnight.

Things between my wife and I have been tense. I tried to sit her down and talk to her about it, but she still insists that it happened and that she doesn't want to talk about it anymore.

This is the first and only time she's made an accusation like this, and of course she does it in front of other people, including an actual DV victim. How should I approach this? Is it even possible to help her realize that it never happened? Is this a sign of something deeper, like maybe her setting herself up for divorce? I don't think she's the type, but before the other day I didn't think she would be the type to accuse me of this bullshit either.

Obviously, I'm deeply offended by this and expect an apology, but I can't even move on to that side of things as long as she keeps insisting it happened. What the fuck am I supposed to do?

TLDR Wife accused me of slapping her but I didn't

Everyone was kind of puzzled, but then she told this story about how when we were first married that we got into a big fight and I supposedly lost my temper and slapped her in the face. This never happened. Anyone who knows me knows that I am not a violent person. I've never hit anyone. I've never even been in a fight in school. I'm the youngest and smallest of four brothers and would routinely get my ass kicked by them, so reacting violently to situations was never my thing. I've never even raised my voice at my wife, which is something she's always hated about me because she feels like I don't show emotion. My friends (male and female) immediately jumped to my defense and said they didn't believe her. Even her own best friend who's known me as long as we've been married didn't seem to believe her. At this point my wife gets upset at the fact that no one believes her and starts to cry. She then starts trying to justify the situation and said that she was the one who was hitting me first and that I responded by slapping her back. The first part is true as she did attack me physically several times in the early years, but I thought we worked through that and nothing like it has happened in a long time. However, again, I NEVER struck her back. One of our friends started talking about false memories and how sometimes we remember things differently as a kind of way to change the conversation. Naturally the party took a weird turn after that and everyone left right after midnight. Things between my wife and I have been tense. I tried to sit her down and talk to her about it, but she still insists that it happened and that she doesn't want to talk about it anymore. This is the first and only time she's made an accusation like this, and of course she does it in front of other people, including an actual DV victim. How should I approach this? Is it even possible to help her realize that it never happened? Is this a sign of something deeper, like maybe her setting herself up for divorce? I don't think she's the type, but before the other day I didn't think she would be the type to accuse me of this bullshit either. Obviously, I'm deeply offended by this and expect an apology, but I can't even move on to that side of things as long as she keeps insisting it happened. What the fuck am I supposed to do? TLDR Wife accused me of slapping her but I didn't

title: I [28F] reported a coworker's [20somethingF] behaviour and am being bullied on social media for it.
selftext:
I work in finance. Fairly big company with a large office. I enjoy my work and get along with everyone there. There are a few older, more experienced people who are team leaders and managers but most of us are young/under 30s. Out of us babies it's about 70/30 girls to guys. I generally hang out with the guys more. I don't dislike the girls but we don't have much in common (they're all graduates from top ranked places which I'm not. They're all very girly and pretty which I'm not etc.). I get along with them well enough though and have them all on social media. 

There's this one guy in the office who barely speaks to anyone. I'll call him Mark. He's actually quite a friendly guy (and not bad looking either!) but is very quiet. He works hard and actually stays in the office when we all go for lunch. Pretty much all of the younger set make fun of him except me (and I do tell the guys to chill out with it), but the managers really like him because of how dedicated he is. 

We were back at work yesterday, and Mark stepped out for something. One of my colleagues, Amanda, sneaked over to his desk for some reason. She looked into his computer, laughed and took a pic. 

I follow her on instagram and she put on her story a picture of Mark's google searches. It included things like ''How to get a girlfriend'', ''Places to meet women'', ''How to talk to women'', ''Places to meet new friends'', etc. Amanda wrote ''Imagine working with people like this #30yearoldvirgin.'' I felt really bad for Mark since he isn't a bad guy at all. 

When he came back I showed him the story and told him we should report her. We did. We spoke to the manager and she said she would deal with it. She called Amanda into the office. Don't know what she said but when Amanda stepped out she was close to tears. She sat down and got on with her work. 

In the evening I was at home when I started getting DMs from some of the other girls in the office, calling me a ''snitch'' and saying they would ''ruin me'' if anything Amanda gets any kind of serious punishment (which I don't think she will). 

I'm worried about this situation. While I don't think anything will happen to Amanda, it won't be a fun place to work with her and her friends there. I can see them really causing trouble for both me and Mark and making work a difficult place to be. 

How do I sort this problem out?

title: My (40M) girlfriend (42F) has stopped contributing financially to our nights out
selftext:
We've been dating to close to 2 years.  At the beginning of the relationship, we would alternate who paid for outings.  One dinner I would pay.  Next dinner would be her treat, etc.

However, about a year into the relationship, she was laid off from her job, so I picked up the slack and started paying for about 90% of our outings.  This went on for several months.

Finally, she found a (rather high paying) job and has been gainfully employed for about 4 months now, making more money than I do.  However, whenever we go out, she gets alligator arms when the bill comes, and I sheepishly end up just paying it.  Instead of going back to sharing expenses like it was when we first dated, it was now "assumed" I would pay for everything.

I've communicated to her about this and she agreed to start contributing.  I said I don't mind paying, but if I'm expected to pay for everything, its severely going to limit how often we are able to go out.  Otherwise, if she wants to go out as often as she does, I expect her to foot the bill sometimes.  She agreed....or so I thought.

Fast forward to NYE planning....I don't like going out.  Its crowded, overpriced, etc.  Not my scene.  However, she wants to go to a fancy restaurant with a couple of her friends (another couple).  I agree to go out, but ask that she at least split the bill with me.  She says Yes.

The dinner goes great and the bill comes.  She hesitates waiting for me to reach for the bill, but I don't.  Instead, I put cash on the table for my half (plus tip).  She gives me the stink eye, and angrily digs in her purse for her credit card.  The rest of NYE was spent with her sulking and ignoring me.

The following day, we are semi-fighting/re-hashing what happened the night prior, with it culminating in her texting "Why the FUCK am I going dutch with my boyfriend of 2 years?"

I've admittedly been out of the dating scene for awhile, after being married for 15 years prior...is it still the expectation that the man pay for everything?  I had (maybe incorrectly) assumed the dating scene was more equal these days.  I feel taken advantage of when I am expected to foot the bill every time....like I'm viewed as a walking ATM.  How can I get her to understand my point of view?  I've spoken with her several times and it seems to go well....until the bill comes and she changes her tune.  

TL;DR:  I (40M) helped to financially support my GF (42F) during her unemployment...paying for every night out.  But now that she's working again, its still assumed that I continue to pay for every evening out.

raw_text: So a few months before last year's Christmas my wife gets upset with about not helping and that I should remember that "acts or service" was her love language and that me taking more initiative in household cleaning chores would help. Admittedly, I had been slacking and made it a point to step up my game. I did and she said even told me so. Now fast forward to that Christmas. We typically have a rule that for Christmas and birthdays we give gifts that the other person wouldn't buy for themselves. But for that Christmas, she wanted to get less expensive gifts. Which would have been fine if she taken the time consider a good gift. Needless to say I was extremely disappointed in my gifts. One was bottle of body wash called Ballwash and the other was a $50 gift card. I should mention that my love language is "receiving gifts" and this hurt me on a couple levels. One was that we had not been intimate in several months and I immediately took this as her making fun of that. Which in turn was making fun of me. Another was that I thought she changed our Christmas tradition just so she did not have to think about anything I liked doing. She couldn't be bothered to spend anytime thinking about me or what I liked doing. I carried that pain/anger/hurt for over a month. I was so mad at her, I contemplated ruining her birthday by giving her some equally awful gift. But my better judgement prevailed and I sat her down to talk about it. There were some tears and misty eyes but I had to tell her or I would have never let it go. During that conversation I told her that for my birthday (which is a fast follow after Christmas) I wanted a particular accessory for one of my hobbies. Now while she didn't exactly what I wanted, she at least tried. Now let's get to this past Christmas. In order to avoid the previous Christmas' fiasco, I started sending Christmas lists to her on the regular. 1.0, 1.1, 1.2 etc. There were plenty of highly detailed and specific gifts of varying price points. And since I started sending them to her in September, she had plenty of time to fit me in her schedule. Now since we share an Amazon account, I can see whenever she orders something. I knew she was getting me a particular tool off the list not only from the order confirmation but she asked me about it two days before that. I was feeling a little down that the surprise was ruined but I was getting a new tool. Christmas day rolls around and it's my turn to open gifts. New tool? Yup. Sweet. I'm thinking that's it because typically stockings are just decoration. But she had our two year old run mine to me. Inside was a map with instructions on where to find the next gift. So me and my son go on a scavenger hunt for all these little gifts scattered around the house. The last gift was a gift card for the accessory I had wanted the previous Christmas. She even said she got similar one at a local store but returned it when she did a little more research into it thinking that it was wrong. She asked me if the first one was correct and I told her either would have been fine. I teared up a little because she did a fantastic job of making me feel special and that she actually was willing to put in the time for me. She showed me that affection is not a one way street and she was willing to do the things that would make me happy. I'm still giddy about it becuase it was so much fun. TLDR; learn how your partner receives love and you'll both be happier.

In particular me, I literally can't casually show emotion, especially affection in my voice, I have to actively try to otherwise I sound monotone usually. It's not that I don't feel emotion or anything, its just that somewhere in between my brain and my mouth the emotion gets lost so even if I'm really happy and feeling affectionate, you can't usually tell by the sound of my voice, but I can casually show emotion and affection in my actions pretty easily, hand holding, hugs, pressing my head on their shoulder, etc so I usually come off as clingy but its literally the only way I can show affection accurately cause my compliments and stuff always sound empty even though they never are

raw_text: Humans are social creatures and have been proven to be far healthier with social interaction; that said, all brains are wired differently and thus require different amounts of mental energy or effort to take part in social interaction, or are more or less sensitive too it. People who are more sensitive to interaction or who require more mental effort to take part in it will often begin to feel drained from it, the same way long hours of menial tasks at an office cubicle may wear on others. I have two metaphors that I have found to be very well received when explaining to my students and friends: 1. All people have skin, and Most people enjoy massages or gentle head rubs. But anyone would say that rubbing the exact same spot for 16 hours straight would make the skin feel raw and sensitive, possibly slightly painful. And there are some with very delicate skin who will reach that point after only an hour or two. It’s not that they suddenly hate being massaged, it’s just that the slight wear on the skin has gotten to a point where they need to take a break from getting rubbed. 2. Everyone needs social interaction, but are sensitive to it on a wide variety of levels. Imagine a large barrel that can be filled with water; this will represent our “social interaction” tank. This tank has a small leak in the bottom, so it must be occasionally topped up. But if you fill it up too much, it overflows and makes a mess everywhere and can be quite the pain to clean up. Many tanks have tops on them, with maybe just a few small holes through which rainwater can enter; this makes them less “sensitive” to the rainwater. Other tanks may have giant holes or no top at all, so rainwater may flow freely into the barrel; making them far more sensitive to rainfall. 6 hours of rain may be a perfect amount to fill a tank with small holes, while the open tank may have started overflowing and making a mess after just 1 hour. It would be better if we could move the open barrel out of the rain after it fills up quickly, so as to avoid making a mess. It will still need to be topped off later as the water slowly leaks out, but RIGHT NOW more water is just making a mess and the barrel needs to be out of the rain for a while. You may be your significant other’s favorite “water”, but too much is too much no matter where it comes from. Just as too much social interaction will make a brain that is more sensitive to it feel raw and sore, or overflowing and out of control.
